text_en: The SE 025 is created in 1971 as a single-seater designed by Abarth for the CSAI, with the goal of offering young Italian drivers an affordable car to train and develop their skills. It is equipped with the 1.6-liter Lampredi twin-cam engine from the Fiat 124 Sport and uses components derived from production models. Lightweight and agile, it exceeds 200 km/h and becomes the star of the Formula Italia Trophy, the single-make championship that launches drivers destined to shine in international competitions such as Riccardo Patrese, Michele Alboreto, and Nicola Larini.

ACMA (Ateliers de Constructions de Motorcycles et Accessoires) was a small French car and motorbike manufacturer active from 1949 to 1962. In 1957 the ACMA Vespa 400 was presented at the Paris Motor Show, developed on the wave of the great success of the Vespa scooter. It was a two-seater compact car with a rear-mounted, forced-air-cooled, 2-stroke twin-cylinder engine and a 3-speed gearbox, which, thanks to its very small size and light weight, combined outstanding handling with low fuel consumption (4.7 l/100 km).

The 155 V6 TI was the latest evolution of the 155 that won the DTM in 1993 with Nicola Larini and only retains the shape of the bodywork from the mass-produced car. All-wheel drive, electronics, near-Formula 1 engines and composite materials: the D1 class regulations are so open that the cars are the most sophisticated, modern and expensive in motorsport. The 1996 season of the ITC – International Touring Car Championship is among the most competitive ever and sees Opel, Mercedes and Alfa Romeo compete. The title is lost to Alfa by only 9 points, after a head-to-head in the last race with Opel.

Famous for being the car featured in the 1967 film
The Graduate
, Alfa Romeo’s spider par excellence has been a success since its presentation at the 1966 Geneva Motor Show. Its original and elegant line was created by the coachbuilder Pininfarina, who designed a two-seat-er spider that was hither to unusual in its kind, with the lenticular shape of the front and convex sides with deep longitudinal indentation and streamlined Plexiglas headlights.

the fullest. Its engine layout freed space at the sides for Venturi tunnels—channels that increased cornering grip and improved high-speed stability.
After a tortuous development, in 1981, with
Mario Andretti
and
Bruno Giacomelli
at the wheel, it became the car to beat. However, changes in regulations prevented it from achieving its full potential. Its best result was a third place for Giacomelli at the Las Vegas Grand Prix.

The Alfa Romeo 6-cylinder 2600, a comfortable, high-class, elegant, and imposing car, was presented at the Geneva Motor Show in 1962. The engine, an evolution of the 2000 model, marked an interesting return to the in-line 6-cylinder, with a light alloy block with removable wet cast-iron liners and upper and lower flanges; it delivered 130 HP at 5900 rpm and allowed a top speed of 200 km/h. From 1962 to 1965, a spider version was also marketed, with bodywork by Touring. In order to improve the design of the soft top, it was necessary to raise the rear and consequently the whole profile of the side of the bodywork, with the result that the 2600 Spider, although very elegant, was not as slender as the previous 2000 Spider.

The offspring of the Tipo 33, that made its debut in 1967, was a completely new car with a tubular chassis and a splendid 3-litre, 12-cylinder, horizontally opposed ‘boxer’ engine designed by engineer Carlo Chiti. It was very powerful and extremely reliable, characterized by its ‘super square’ geometric dimensions: diameter of the cylinders 77 mm, stroke 53.6 mm, thanks to which maximum power reached 11000 rpm. This car would also appear in Formula 1, with Brabham and Alfa Romeo itself. The bodywork was designed by the young engineer Michel Tétu, Chiti’s assistant, with great attention to aerodynamics and a wing to ensure the best grip for the rear wheels

A powerful and extremely fast car, the characteristic of this famous Alfa (a sports spider bodied by Touring on the Alfa Romeo 2300 chassis) was  the possibility of being used both as a touring car and in a racing version. Driven by the greatest racers of the time  (including Nuvolari, Borzacchini, Brivio, Sommer, Chinetti, and Campari), it was the winner of a prolonged series of both road and circuit races. These included the Mille Miglia, Italian Grand Prix, 24 Hours of Le Mans (won four years in a row), Monaco Grand Prix, and Targa Florio.

Alfa Romeo built a dozen or so competition models with 2-, 3-, and 3.5-litre engines. One of these cars, a 6C 3000 CM, driven by Juan Manuel Fangio, finished second overall in the 1953 Mille Miglia. In a similar model Fangio also won the first Supercortemaggiore Grand Prix, held in Merano in the same year. The model donated to the Museum by Alfa Romeo in 1956 was built with a 2-litre engine and fitted with the powerful 6-cylinder engine of the 6C 3000.

The Alfa Romeo Giulietta Sprint coupé, mass-produced by Bertone, was one of the most representative models of Italian automotive style and engineering in the 1950s. The Sprint version, with its brilliant performance, remained in production from 1954 to 1966 and preceded the Giulietta saloon and Pininfarina bodied spider by a year, followed by other purely sporty variations, right up to the larger Giulia series. Production of the various versions of the Giulietta continued for eleven years with a total of 177,513 units manufactured.

The Alfetta was the car that marked Alfa Romeo’s return to racing after the war, ushering a new era of success built on unmatched technical mastery.
In 1950, it made motor racing history: with
Nino Farina
at the wheel, it won the first official Formula 1 World Championship, paving the way for an unprecedented sporting legend. Further refinements to the engine and chassis secured another world title the following year, this time with
Juan Manuel Fangio
.

The car on display at the Museum is Varzi’s legendary P2 of the Targa Florio, a powerful and rugged car, the star of an incredible victory achieved in spite of unforeseen events (a punctured fuel tank and a fire put out with seat cushions).

A masterpiece by Giuseppe Merosi, the RL is the first project of the Romeo era. Fast, elegant and refined, it was also successful abroad: it was in production between 1925 and 1927, for an international clientele that loved excellent performance. It was powered by an in-line 6-cylinder engine, while the standard chassis could be bodied as required by individual customers. In its various versions, the RL achieved both sales successes and magnificent sporting results, with the SS – Super Sport version featuring a dry sump lubricated engine with a displacement of 2994 cc.

On the eve of World War I, Fiat entered three cars in the Grand Prix of the Automobile Club of France. The race, held on 5 July 1914 and won by Christian Lautenschlager’s Mercedes, also featured the Fiat S 57/14 B.
The car returned to racing after the war, continuing to distinguish itself for its competitiveness and reliability. Among its most notable results were victory in the Parma–Poggio
di Berceto hill climb in 1919 with
Antonio Ascari
, and the triumph at the Targa Florio in 1921 with
Guido Masetti
.

The result of the ambitious project that saw the union of Fiat, Bianchi and Pirelli, which would give rise to Autobianchi, the Bianchina was the first ‘special’ car to be built in Italy on an industrial scale using the mechanical parts of an existing model (Fiat Nuova 500). The engine and mechanical components were sourced from the Fiat Mirafiori plant and Autobianchi was responsible for assembling them on a body of its own design and production, designed by Fabio Luigi Rapi. Always carefully designed and with attention to every detail, around 300,000 units were manufactured, with several versions available: from the convertible model to the cabriolet, from the hard top to the custom-built versions, to the four-seater saloon and the Panoramica.

Benz is one of the world’s oldest car manufacturers, founded by German engineer Karl Benz, considered the father of the automobile because he introduced the world to the first commercially available car because of his Patent Motorwagen in 1886. It was a three-wheeler with a 577 cc single-cylinder rear engine, which received a certain amount of media attention thanks to an unintentional test carried out by Benz’s wife, who, keeping her husband in the dark, used the vehicle on a 90-kilometre journey: it was proof that the ‘horseless carriage’ was not just a laboratory experiment.

Professor Enrico Bernardi from Verona was one of the greatest pioneers of the automobile, and to him we owe important inventions and patents, including his first patent for a petrol engine and its application to a three-wheeler, the first vehicle to circulate on the Italian roads. He began studying internal combustion engines as early as 1876 and in 1882 built the Pia engine (named after his daughter) which, applied to a sewing machine, was presented at the 1884 National Exhibition in Turin. In the same year, he applied the Pia engine to his son’s toy tricycle, which he used on the streets of Quinzano in Verona. Later, the same engine was used to power a three-wheeled car. The 3½ HP was his first three-wheeled car.

The Isetta is a city car (i.e., a car characterised by its small size, practicality, and low fuel consumption) produced by the Italian car manufacturer Iso based in Bresso (Milan) between 1953 and 1956 and, under licence, by the German company BMW between 1955 and 1962. The BMW 250, the German Isetta, retains all the insights of the Iso, with the addition of a small but effective heating system and sliding side windows. From a mechanical point of view, the novelty lay in the adoption of a 4-stroke engine, with a slightly modified displacement (245 cc) which justified the new name, and power increased to 12 HP. In 1956, this version was joined by the 300 with an upgraded 13 HP engine.

Brixia-Züst, a subsidiary of Züst, was founded in Brescia in March 1906. The first car to be produced was the 14/18 HP, built from 1906 to 1911, with a 4-cylinder engine of 3770 cc displacement, chassis with longitudinal side members and cardan shaft drive. However, the most successful model, and the most interesting mechanically, was the 10 HP with a fixed-head monobloc with side valves controlled by two camshafts in the crankcase and a 3-speed mechanical gearbox, produced between 1908 and 1911. Brixia-Züst was in fact one of the few factories to attempt the experiment of the engine with three vertical cylinders

The 41 C Special is a model with a design that is still majestic, but modern and well balanced throughout. The length of the bonnet is accentuated by the grille divided into two parts; the front end is enhanced by the elongated shape of the two headlights mount- ed on either side of the nose and the two tail lights at the tips of the large mudguards. The doors open like a cupboard, but the body has a central pillar. The window area is modest in relation to the car’s volume, while the V-shaped windscreen contributes to the body line. The built-in boot is one of the earliest examples of a three-box design.

The 62 model (descendant of the 60 series) marked the peak of the Detroit company’s worldwide resonance and was produced in successive versions, with coupé, convertible, or saloon bodywork, until 1964. The car on display is a Fischer-bodied saloon version and was the model in the range with the highest number of units produced: 42,625.

The 5 HP model was the first produced by Fratelli Ceirano, founded in 1901 by Giovanni Battista Ceirano, together with his brother Matteo, importing a series of 5, 8, 10, 12 and 16 horsepower cars. From 1902 onwards, the company sought the technical advice of engineer Alberto Balloco to design its cars, and in the spring of 1903, it presented the 16 HP model, one of the most technically innovative cars of the small Turin-based company. The 5 HP model has a 639 cc single- cylinder vertical Aster engine at the front and a patented 4-speed gearbox with gears that are always engaged. An interesting feature of this model are also the two side water radiators.

Cisitalia was founded by Piero Dusio in Turin in 1946 and became known for producing exceptional cars from both a styling and technical point of view. At the dawn of the 1950s, the 202 would single-handedly signify the notion of Grand Touring: its lines of absolute purity represented a breakthrough in car design. From then on, the lines of a car would no longer have anything to do with the past, and would be truly Italian in design, thanks to the pencil strokes of Giovanni Savonuzzi and Giovanni Battista Farina, on an Italian chassis and mechanics.

It was a very original car, with pronounced fins and a very flattened bonnet and bodywork made by Stabilimenti Farina (where Alfredo Vignale, who later founded his company, worked), full wheel fairing and profiling studied at the Wind Tunnel of the Polytechnic Univeristy of Turin. The open version of this model, with an all-aluminium body and much less pronounced fins, was entered in the 1947 Mille Miglia and was driven by Nuvolari, who would go on to write one of the most exciting pages in motor sport.

It was designed by the engineer André Lefèbvre, a great innovator who had introduced the use of metal bodies to Europe (from a patent purchased in the United States) by presenting the Citroën B12 in 1925, and designed by the Italian Flaminio Bertoni, one of the greatest stylists in automotive history. Named ‘Traction Avant’ due to the application of traction to the front wheels, its avant-garde solution was an aerodynamic bodywork with a steel load-bearing body, which made it possible to create a single body between chassis and bodywork. Added to this were other cutting-edge features such as four-wheel independent suspension with torsion bars, front axle shafts with constant velocity joints, overhead valve engine and removable liners.

Presented at the 1955 Paris Motor Show, the Citroën DS 19, known as ‘La Déesse’, had nothing in common with the cars manufactured up to that time in Europe and around the world, either in terms of its technical features or its futuristic lines, designed by the father of the Traction Avant and the 2CV, the Italian Flaminio Bertoni. When designing the body, he chose to work with clay and carefully modelled an aerodynamic hatchback body, low and wide, with slender pillars, a large window area, a panoramic windscreen and rear window with curves that joined the windows, in harmony with the horizontal beltline.

Born on 22 September 1855 in Pierre- fond (in northern France), Adolphe Clément became one of France’s leading industrialists through ingenious intuitions that enabled him to reap all the benefits of a world in profound evolution, thanks to cycling, tyres and motoring. In 1891, the first developmental move was the purchase of a huge piece of land in Levallois Perret, the future industrial suburb of Paris, to install a velodrome (1893). The 3 HP model appeared on the market in 1899, but without much success because of its outdated mechanical solutions.

The L29 was the world’s first production front-wheel drive model, a solution chosen by Cord to give its new line a distinctive element compared to the rest of the American automotive manufacturing industry. However, it wasn’t just this technical and, in a sense, tactical choice that made the car successful. Much can be attributed to the proportions of the bodywork. The low, straight chassis, together with the slender bonnet which, since it had to house an 8-cylinder engine in line with the transmission unit, was almost half the length of the entire vehicle, gave the car aggressive, prestigious lines that all the designers of other car manufacturers immediately had to con- tend with.

The factory began producing motor three-wheelers in the late 19th century. The model on display is a three-wheeled Tri (from the word ‘Three-wheeler’ or ‘Tricar’) model, powered by an air- cooled single-cylinder De Dion engine, located behind the rear axle and with a gear transmission. Thousands of these three-wheelers were built over a period of about ten years. It was a De Dion three-wheeler that sparked Carlo Biscaretti’s great passion for cars.

Built entirely by
Paolo Deideri
—a mechanic by trade and by passion—the car was first exhibited at the Museum in 1970 on the occasion of the fourth Competition Cars Exhibition.
Although it remained a prototype, it showcased some remarkable features: designed for Formula 3, it was powered by an Alfa Romeo Giulietta engine and fitted with a low-cost fibreglass body—just 12,000 lire—that offered surprisingly good aerodynamics. Capable of reaching 230 km/h, it embodies the inventive spirit that fuelled motorsport in those years.

1910 was a productive year for Delage. This is thanks to the introduction of the 4-cylinder 12 HP type AB and 4-cylinder 10 HP type AC models – both powered by Ballot engines. The AB model, which was to be produced in nine series, was powered by the Ballot 4F engine for the first three, and the Ballot 4FM engine for the fourth through to the ninth series. The eighth series AB 4 was distinguished by its refined mechanics, 4-cylinder engine of 2.1 litres, and 12 HP. All this contributed to the car’s lightness and purity of body lines. The Museum bought it for 6,000 francs from a Lyon dealer in 1963 “complete, running, and in excellent condition”, as well as featuring a long list of accessories.

After successful models such as the 10, 20 and 30 and sporting successes in which Alfieri Maserati’s genius was evident, the troubled financial situation forced production to be limited to spare parts, compressors, and generators, to be ceased definitively in 1955. A key feature of the Model 30 was its powerful 2-litre engine with overhead valve timing, which had been adopted by Diatto since 1919.

The first model built was the type A 6/8 HP with a characteristic circular radiator and a cast-iron 2-cylinder 1135 cc mono- bloc engine positioned at the front. The valves were lateral, located on the left side and controlled by the camshaft in the crankcase, which was connected to a gearbox to operate the magnet. The gearbox was a 3-speed plus reverse with a leather-covered cone clutch and cardan shaft transmission. The chassis was made of pressed steel with leaf spring suspension and wooden spoked wheels with 700 x 80 mm tyres. Brakes only on the rear wheels with a dual system, hand-operated on the wheels while the pedal operated the drum at the gearbox exit. The characteristic round design of the front end was determined by the adoption of a radiator with a fan driven by a steel spring.

Developed by Ferrari’s racing department to meet the new Formula 1 regulations introduced in 1961, this single-seater marked the debut of a young
Mauro Forghieri
—destined to become one of the engineers of the Prancing Horse.
On its debut, the car won the Constructors’ Championship and the Drivers’ title with the American
Phil Hill
. The example on display also achieved two prestigious victories in 1963, when
John Surtees
triumphed at the German and Mediterranean Grands Prix.

The last front-engined single-seater from Maranello, the 246 F1 marked a pivotal stage in racing history. With this car,
Mike Hawthorn
won the 1958 Drivers’ World Championship—the first for a British driver. The model remained in competition until 1960, when it took victory at Monza in the Italian Grand Prix—the final Formula 1 win for a front-engined car.
In 2001, Ferrari, in collaboration with the Museum, restored the example on display to its original splendour, using period materials and drawings.

Six models were manufactured for Jody Scheckter (who had the car marked number 1) and Gilles Villeneuve, who drove the car on display. However, that sporting season was not the most brilliant. It was donated to the Museum by Ferrari on 28 April 1982, ten days before the fatal accident at Zolder in which the great driver Villeneuve lost his life.

This four-seater luxury grand tourer boasted excellent mechanic components in true Ferrari style. In fact, its 12-cylinder 60° V engine – initially used exclusively in racing events – was later applied to road models. The engine was mounted longitudinally, which explains its flat and wide bonnet. Its most noticeable characteristic was its 4-shaft timing system. While its design appealed to overseas tastes, it was never sold in America. Furthermore, it was never popular in Europe, even though its mechanics offered very high performance.

The Ferrari 500 F2 was created in 1951, when
Enzo Ferrari
decided to focus on Formula 2—a less costly and more manageable alternative to Formula 1.
A year later, the car was admitted to Formula 1, where it quickly became the undisputed star until the regulation changes of 1954. Driven by
Alberto Ascari
, the Prancing Horse single-seater claimed two consecutive World Championships. With 31 victories out of 35 Grands Prix, it is still remembered today as one of the most successful Ferraris in history.

Driven by
Felipe Massa
and
Kimi Räikkönen
under new Team Principal
Stefano Domenicali
, the F2008 earned Maranello its sixteenth Constructors’ title after a season of remarkable consistency: eight victories, eight pole positions, and thirteen fastest laps.
The Drivers’ title, however, slipped away in dramatic fashion. Massa won the final race in Brazil and, for a few seconds, appeared to be World Champion—until Lewis Hamilton passed Timo Glock on the last lap, finishing fifth and taking the title by a single point.

The 12/16 HP model was developed by Giovanni Enrico with a large displacement 4-cylinder 2-block engine and the first of the Turin-based manufacturer to use a trapezoidal (honeycomb) Mégevet type radiator. Built in 110 units, it was also the first Fiat model to be exported worldwide. Aside from its technical characteristics, the model on display also boasts a ‘tonneau’ body with a sophisticated design. In fact, it features a laminated wood surface with exposed fibres protected by a single coat of transparent lacquer, just as on the most prestigious yachts

Fiat 130 HP had vertical, 4-cylinder, 2-piece engines, four gears, chain drive, foot brake on the differential, wooden wheels and a low-tension magneto system. Derived from the 100/110 HP type, whose design was entrusted to engineer Giovanni Enrico. This giant car featured over 16 litres of displacement. Furthermore, it was characterized by overhead valve timing in a 90° V shape, with a power of 130 HP and a weight of 1,025 kg, capable of reaching a speed of 160 km/h, with peaks of up to 200 km/h

Produced by Fiat from 1907 onward, inheriting a large portion of the mechanic components of the 16/20 HP model, it is a medium-powered car with a 2-block engine and a chain transmission. One of the most important features of this model is the use of a unique type of engine starting device which relies on compressed air provided by a special compressor. The 400 units of this car were built in three different wheelbases to accommodate different body types, obtaining great success also abroad.

Fiat’s 1900 model, introduced in 1952 and derived from the 1400, was for some years at the top of Fiat’s range. The later Granluce version had particular traits of elegance and refinement: the body, with only two doors, was distinguished by the shape of the roof with the large wraparound rear window, the absence of a pillar between the side windows, the design of the grille and the two-tone paintwork. Engine power was increased from 70 to 80 HP (top speed increased by 10 km/h) and a so-called booster was added to the braking system, along with the adoption of tubeless tyres.

Fiat started mass production with the 3½ HP model, of which 30 examples were built. Developed by engineer Aristide Faccioli and derived from the Welleyes 3½ HP built by Giovanni Ceirano, the Fiat 3½ HP model was released a few months after the company was founded. The distinctive feature of this ‘little car’ is the rear-mounted, twin-cylinder engine, water-cooled by way of a serpentine radiator, with three-speed gearbox without reverse and chain drive. Fuel consumption was about 8 l/100 km.

The 500 “Topolino” (unofficial name given by the public, never endorsed by Fiat)  is characterised by a very simple production process: a small 4-cylinder engine assembled with a cantilever system in front of the wheel axle, independent front wheels, and a two-seater body with an unmistakable style. Consumption was only 6 litres per 100 km. At the time of its release, it cost 8,900 Italian lire and contributed significantly to the spread of this car in Italy. Until 1955, it was produced in three series, with a total of almost 520,000 units, including the ‘Giardiniera’ version.

In July 1957, the Fiat Nuova 500 was born in Turin, in the Mirafiori plant. Its launch was not a happy one, it even risked being a failure. It was to be the ultimate utility car, an automobile able to appeal to those who previously had used only bicycles. Its purpose was to replace the ‘Topolino’ launched in 1936 and take the lead in a segment where the Fiat 600 (manufactured two years earlier in 1955) had ranked second. In the era of the italian economic ‘boom’, it was to become a true phenomenon of custom: a popular and transverse car, that was able to motorise even workers and women, as well as serving as the second car of those who already owned one

The 501 was the popular post-war car par excellence. In fact, undoubtedly, it was one of those that formed the backbone of Italian motoring for almost a decade. In 1922, the 501 model was followed by the sporty 501 S and 501 SS models. As compared to the basic version with a 23 HP engine, the 501 S version had an upgraded engine with 26.5 HP, a more compressed engine, a different camshaft, longer axle ratios, and a higher speed. It was followed by many other versions built by skilled and attentive bodywork mechanics, who recognized the 501 S as a car that was able to combine sporty characteristics with low costs

Designed by engineer Fessia, the Fiat 508 (known as the ‘Balilla’) was the most popular utility car of its time. It was presented at the Milan Motor Show in 1932. An ultra-modern vehicle with a simple mechanics, it featured a 4-cylinder, less than one-litre engine with side valves, a 3-speed transmission, and innovative hydraulic brakes. Offered as two-door saloon, torpedo, and spider body styles, as well as a sporty version later on, this car was a huge success because of its economy, robustness, and outstanding performance.

A mid-upper class model with a 6-cylinder engine and side valves, the 520 was the forerunner of a long series of Fiat 6-cylinder cars. It was a rational, modern car and the first left-hand drive car in Italy. More than 20,000 examples were built between 1927 and 1929 and were available in torpedo, saloon, cabriolet, spider and taxi versions. The saloon cost 31,000 Italian lire at the time of launch.

First project carried out under the responsibility of the technical director – engineer Giovanni Enrico – it was also the first Fiat to feature an engine with two vertical cylinders on the front of the car, housed in a sort of bonnet, mid-mounted gearbox and rear-wheel drive. The honeycomb radiator would replace the serpentine radiator later. Production lasted only two years, but the model made history when eight of these 8 HP cars participated in the first edition of the legendary Giro d’Italia in 1901, covering a distance of 1640 kilometres.

On the eve of World War I, Fiat entered three cars in the Grand Prix of the Automobile Club of France. The race, held on 5 July 1914 and won by Christian Lautenschlager’s Mercedes, also featured the Fiat S 57/14 B.
The car returned to racing after the war, continuing to distinguish itself for its competitiveness and reliability. Among its most notable results were victory in the Parma–Poggio
di Berceto hill climb in 1919 with
Antonio Ascari
, and the triumph at the Targa Florio in 1921 with
Guido Masetti
.

Considered to be Fiat’s first small car, it was a vehicle that certainly was not affordable for the middle class. It featured a large displacement and elaborate bodywork thanks to the prototype design at Stabilimento Farina, among the most prominent centres of Turin’s automotive style. Featuring a very simple, robust, and reliable mechanical structure, the fan mounted behind the radiator – and driven by a belt transmission – appears for the first time in this model.

The car chassis derived from the Fiat 8V, with a two-seater ‘berlinetta’ body with excellent aerodynamic profile, pop-up headlights and fins on the two rear mudguards. The car reached a top speed of 260 km/h during track tests at Lingotto and Caselle, driven by Carlo Salamano (both a driver and test driver). The car was presented at the Turin Motor Show in April 1954. However, it remained a research and experimental prototype until being donated to the Turin Automobile Museum in the 1960s.

The car on display at the Museum, the only Florentia 10 HP in the world, has a ‘tonneau’ body, a 2-cylinder engine, a cardan shaft transmission and an innovative fan cooling system that was able to work efficiently for about 500km with 8-9 litre of water. It was bought in 1967 by Baron Giorgio Franchetti, a well-known Roman patron and one of the pioneers of car collecting in Italy.

FOD stood for Fonderie Officine De Benedetti, founded in Turin in 1915 by Francesco De Benedetti. FOD’s construction technique followed an innovative and original path. Their vehicle was a kind of cyclecar, characterized by the extensive use of light alloys in all its mechanical parts. It had simple, basic suspension, but a refined engine: a tiny 565 cc 4-cylinder with an overhead camshaft, lightened connecting rods and, in some cases, roller bearings. The valve rocker arms were cast in light alloy, as were the clutch assembly, the gear chains with their forks and the wheel hubs.

Robust and tireless, the Jeep was used in a wide variety of applications: as a means of exploration, an infantry attack vehicle, an amphibian vehicle, a rescue vehicle, etc., until it became synonymous with the four-wheel drive off-road vehicle. By the end of the war, 737,770 examples had been produced, of which 459,874 by Willys and 277,896 by Ford.

The Ford Model T is one of the most famous cars in history. With 15 million units produced between 1908 and 1927, it is considered the masterpiece of Hen- ry Ford, who wanted a simple, inexpensive car that could be mass-produced and sold at a low price. And in the famous words of Henry Ford: “Any customer can have a car painted any colour that he wants, so long as it is black”.  Around the Model T, the modern assembly line and a new way of organizing industry was born in the United States, aiming to sell the product to its own workers, while in Europe, during the same period, the car was still a ‘toy’ for the lucky few

The Lele was built in 1969 as a one-off for an American customer who wanted a high-performance coupé with Italian styling. Designed by Marcello Gandini, designer for the coachbuilder Bertone, the Lele is a modern and luxurious 2+2 grand tourer with Corvette mechanics. Piero Rivolta, who took over the company after the death of his father Renzo, decided to present it at the New York Motor Show, in order to target the North American market with a new car and decided to name it Lele in tribute to his wife

950 units of the 8A model were produced, with a selling price of 140,000 Italian lire for the chassis alone, rising to over 185,000 lire with a ‘landaulet’ body. It was a very luxurious and refined car, destined for the richest and most famous people of the time and loved above all by the international jet-set. The car on display, bodied as a ‘coupé de ville’ by Castagna of Milan, was used in 1950 for the filming of Sunset Boule- vard starring William Holden, Erich von Stroheim and Gloria Swanson as Norma Desmond, whose initials are engraved on the car’s rear doors

The ABC-type children’s car was built by Isotta Fraschini between 1928 and 1929 to a design by Guido Cattaneo. It was powered by a real Peugeot 4-cylinder engine of around 700 cc, the one from the ‘Quadrilette’ utility car, mounted on a lowered chassis and enhanced by a real radiator. It had a real gearbox and, in general, an orthodox mechanical layout of a car in miniature.

Designed by engineer
Giulio Cesare Cappa
, the Itala 11 was created as a single-seater racing car for the
1925
Monza Grand Prix for Vetturette. It was intended to relaunch the company’s racing ambition, but economic difficulties prevented production—the car remained a prototype and never competed.
The example on display still bears on its body the marks left by bombing during World War II, a testament to its long and eventful history.

One of the most interesting innovations at that time was the design of the ‘avalve’ or valveless engine by engineer Balocco, presented at the 1911 Turin Motor Show. In this engine, the distribution was not implemented with traditional valves, but with sliding or rotating valve liners: it was an extremely quiet engine, as all valve play was eliminated, and very reliable, as the wear process of the components was very slow. The 25/35 HP model, despite being technically conventional and lacking the expensive ‘avalve’ engine used at the time, was very well built, robust and reliable, so much so that it remained in production, without any particular variations, until the end of 1915.

An undisputed symbol of the wave of modernity that the automobile represented in the last century, the Itala model 35/45 HP is the protagonist of the legendary race from Peking to Paris in 1907. Specially equipped for the race, Scipione Borghese’s Itala (later called Peking-Paris) had three large fuel tanks – two 150-litre tanks on the side and one 80-litre tank at the rear of the car – and was powered by a 7-litre engine with a 4-speed gearbox. The wheels were larger than the factory model, of equal diameter in the front and rear axles to limit stock, with wooden rims that were easier to repair and long ash boards instead of mudguards.

Itala’s prestige was such that it was one of the car manufacturers favoured by the Royal House of Savoy, in particular by Queen Margherita, for whom this 35/45 HP Itala was built. She christened it ‘Palombella’ and its refined bodywork was executed in Milan by Cesare Sala, one of the leading coachbuilders of the time. The chassis is identical to that of the famous Itala that won the Peking to Paris race in 1907, except for a few modifications, for example the two brakes controlled by separate pedals. Note the silver eagle-shaped handles and the fold- down access ladder under the door in this luxurious ‘limousine landaulet’.

Vincenzo Lancia, true to his innovative intuition, believed that the public was ready for a new creation, so he gave a few, precise directives: a light, aerodynamic, quick, and manoeuvrable car with an engine displacement between the Augusta’s 1200 and 1500 cc. A few months later, a lightweight and powerful 4-cylinder narrow V-shaped engine with an aluminium monobloc and cast-iron liners was created. The innovative line of the car was the result of studies carried out in the aerodynamic research laboratory of the Polytechnic University of Turin.

A symbol of elegance, the Aurelia was the first new car presented by Lancia after the war. This modern and refined car was also innovative as in the best tradition of the Turin-based company. This was most notably due to its extraordinary 6-cylinder V engine, the first in the world, created by engineer Francesco De Virgilio, and for the original rear axle with independent wheels and gearbox and brakes in block with the differential. The ‘B20’ version, presented in 1951, a year after the saloon, with shortened wheel- base, upgraded engine, and Pininfarina coupé bodywork, introduced the ‘Gran Turismo’ formula

The Lancia D24, the final stage in the development of Progetto Sport according to Jano’s programme, made its debut at the 1,000 km race on the Nürburgring at the end of August 1953. It was a splendid car, beautifully bodied by Pininfarina, with an engine completely redesigned by Ettore Zaccone Mina, based on the experience gained during a season with the D20: 6-cylinder 60° V-shaped engine, 4 overhead camshafts, two in each bank of cylinders and dual ignition, displacement 3300 cc. The bodywork was elegant and functional, some 50 kg lighter than the D23

Designed by
Vittorio Jano
, this Formula 1 single-seater made its debut at the 1954 Spanish Grand Prix with
Alberto Ascari
. The first successes came the following year, with victories at the Turin and Naples Grands Prix.
Ascari’s tragic death at Monza in 1955, however, marked the end of Lancia’s direct involvement in racing. The six cars built were handed over to Ferrari, which continued their development. With this car—renamed the Lancia–Ferrari D50—
Juan Manuel Fangio
won the 1956 World Championship.

The model on show, destined for mass production, is the Delta Integrale Evoluzione, produced from 1991 to 1993, with a 16-valve engine, a Martini livery (used in competitions), and many aesthetic touches such as enlarged track widths, side curves, different bumpers and mechanical improvements (to the suspension, brakes, steering box and electronics). The price was appropriate for the performance levels: about 45 million lire.

Production of the Flaminia saloon began in 1957 and the car quickly established itself as one of the most luxurious and refined of the period. Its career began in 1957, but production of the 2.8 – built until 1970 – began in 1963. Comfortable and beautifully finished, many special versions were made, including the Zagato coupé. Among the special, non-series models, the most famous is the long-wheel- base ‘cabriolet-landaulet’ version that Pininfarina created, with only four units built, for the Presidency of the Italian Republic between 1960 and 1961. The mechanics were the same as those of the Flaminia saloon 2500, with the exception of the gearbox and axle ratios, which were reduced to allow a parade speed.

The skeleton of the body, instead of wood, is made of 2 mm thick stamped sheet steel (‘emboutie’), surrounded on the outside by thin sheet steel as well, while on the inside the padding and cushions are movable; the two front ends close in a frame enclosing the radiator. Lengthways, the bodywork is crossed by an arched profile, a tunnel shape – which seems to divide it into two equal parts – in which the cardan transmission shaft runs. This shaping, which acts almost like a reinforced bridge, contributes to increasing the car’s rigidity and cohesion by lowering its centre of gravity.

Photographer Cirani spent 1,500 hours to fit out the vehicle. Exterior accessories included a roof tent, several fuel tanks (giving it a range of 1,100 km on normal roads and 6/700 km on difficult roads), a double spare wheel and additional headlights. Inside, in addition to clothing, spare parts, and hardware, all the photographic equipment was loaded, a refrigerator (there was also a small fridge for photographic film), a kitchen cooker and a special drinking water circuit with a double tank and internal taps.

Presented at the 1974 Geneva Motor Show at Giovanni Michelotti’s booth, this original two-seater electric city car, with a name reminiscent of the lunar module but actually an acronym for “Laboratorio Elettrico Mobile”. Its most original feature is its load-bearing structure, made of riveted duralumin sheet metal (according to the technique used at the time for the most advanced single-seater racing cars) so as to obtain a total weight, without batteries, of just 350 kg: an exceptionally modest weight for a car with independent suspension, a hydraulic braking system (with regenerative braking, i.e., recovery of kinetic energy during braking), a complex electrical and electronic system, and a comfortable, well-finished body.

Léon Bollée, son of the great pioneer of steam locomotion Amédée, started the automobile business with a patent registered on 4 December 1895 for a three-wheeler tandem powered by a single-cylinder 650 cc engine developing 3 HP, air cooling, glow tube ignition, three speeds and a tubular frame. The clutch, gearbox and brake controls were operated by a single lever. The three-wheeler immediately attracted a lot of interest, and its construction was initially entrusted to the company Hurtu, Diligeont et Cie, and then to Société des Voiturettes Système Léon Bollée, based in Paris. The Bollée 3 HP made its debut on 14 September 1896 in the Paris-Marseille- Paris race and two years later reached 60 km/h on the flying kilometre.

It is one of the most famous Formula 1 cars, described by Denis Jenkinson as “the immortal single-seater”. It remained a major force in Grand Prix racing for seven years, from 1954 to 1960, with 42 victories at circuits around the world. The most successful season for the Maserati 250F was 1957, with victories in the Argentine, Monaco, French and German Grands Prix, and Juan Manuel Fangio winning the Drivers’ World Championship and the Constructors’ Cup, a source of pride for every car manufacturer.

Developed from the Tipo 26—the first car to bear the Trident badge—the 26B was, in the words of the
Maserati brothers
, “the first car built in our workshop”.
With
Alfieri Maserati
at the wheel, it achieved third place overall at the 1927 Targa Florio. Despite Alfieri’s career being cut short by a serious crash at the Coppa di Messina, the car continued racing and, in 1928, won the Italian Manufacturers’ Championship—one of the first major sporting triumphs for the young Modena-based company.

The 1960s marked a decline for the Trident brand in terms of sporting achievements, especially on the international stage . The prototype of the Maserati Mexico, fitted out for a South American client by the Turin-based coachbuilder Vignale as a 2+2 seater sports saloon, appeared at the 1965 Turin Motor Show. The final four-seater version was presented at the Paris Motor Show the following year with a 4.7-litre engine that was joined from 1969 by the smaller 402 with the same fittings. Built until 1973, only 250 units of the Maserati Mexico were produced

This luxury sports car immediately became the most sought-after vehicle by both the old aristocracy and the emerging bourgeoisie. In fact, they appreciated its elegant and austere forms as well as its top-level performance (thanks to its 8-cylinder in-line engine), supercharged by a volumetric compressor that could be switched on from the driver’s seat, as well as its four-wheel independent suspension. Its 5-litre-plus engine pro- duces 180 HP – an enormous amount for the time – and makes it a car capable of high performance on the road, although it never excelled in motorsport events. What is most striking about this car is its size, grandeur, style and finish.

Its first victory coincided with its debut in the 1954 French Grand Prix at Reims, with Juan Manuel Fangio and Karl Kling coming in first and second. At the wheel of the W196 R Fangio won the world titles in 1954 and 1955. Fifteen units were produced, one of which was donated to the Museum in 1957 with a letter from Nallinger, Chefingenieur of Daimler-Benz, followed by a second one from Alfred Neubauer himself.

Monaco’s project was aimed at demonstrating two technical principles, both of which – many decades later – were widely adopted by the global automotive industry: air-cooling of the engine and front-wheel drive. For the engine he chose a J.A.P. twin- cylinder featuring 80 x 99 mm, 998 cc total displacement, and two overhead valves for each cylinder. The engine was lubricated by three pumps: the first pump sent oil to the crankshaft, another to the right-hand cylinder, and the third to the timing components as well as valve guides.

Designed by technician
Augusto Monaco
together with driver
Carlo Felice Trossi
, the Monaco Trossi was unveiled in 1935 and tested during practice for the Italian Grand Prix at Monza. Its innovative features were remarkable: weighing only 710 kg—well below the 750 kg limit set by regulations—it was equipped with a unique front-wheel-drive power unit.
Despite its potential, the car proved too unstable and difficult to control at high speed. It never progressed beyond the testing stage and remained a prototype.

After being exhibited at the Ghia stand at the Turin Motor Show in 1956, the new Nibbio was tested on 28 March 1956 on the high-speed track at Monza. The following 6 June, again on the Monza circuit, the vehicle driven by Lurani and Campanella set its first international record, that of the D class (up to 350 cc) over 3 hours, covering 394.037 kilometres, at an average speed of 131.345 km/h. This same record was improved by the Nibbio on 26 April the following year when Campanella, Poggio and Volpini lapped Monza for three hours at an average speed of 141.643 km/h.

In 1967 the Ro80 was presented, a truly innovative model that was at the cutting edge of the brand’s production. But the real revolution was in the rotary piston engine, patented by Wankel, which had aroused great interest in the 1960s due to the absence of mechanical parts with reciprocating motion and thus its silent qualities. Many manufacturers experimented with it at the time, but in the end, it was only the old Neckarsulm company that put it into production.

Named for the characteristic front part of the bodywork, curved upwards like a sledge, it was easy to drive and repair, and for these reasons was a great commercial success. To meet demand, production times were accelerated by outsourcing everything possible: engines to Leland & Faulconer, gearboxes to Dodge Brothers, bodies to Briscoe and interiors to B.F. Everitt. A moving production, which already encapsulated the concept of bringing the work to the worker, and not the worker to the work (the basic principle of the subsequent Fordism), was matched by a similar movement in sales, partly thanks to the many advertising gimmicks devised by Ransom.

Sports version of the car built in 1922 by OM (Officine Meccaniche) in Brescia and which remained in production until 1934. The technical features were similar to those of its predecessor, the 465, but rapid technical progress had allowed a significant increase in engine power, improving performance and reliability. The 469 excelled in com- petition, both in the racing category, normally bodied with two bucket seats on a bare chassis, and in the ‘touring’ category. Its name, 469, is due to the number of cylinders in the engine for the first digit, while the other two indicate the bore size.

Released in 1926 and christened ‘Superba’, the OM 665 is the model that most enriched the brand’s reputation. The OM 665 N5, presented in 1929, is the dazzling touring version of this model, with its capacity increased to 2200 cc. Road holding (which was exceptional for the period), smoothness of the gearbox, effective brakes, and great acceleration as well as overall manoeuvrability were the characteristics commonly highlighted in the articles. Furthermore, the latter emphasised that the car had enough speed and torque to satisfy even the sportiest customer.

One of the largest and oldest brands in US automotive history, Packard (founded 1899) is known for its meticulous construction, 12-cylinder luxury cars (said to have inspired even Enzo Ferrari), pioneering sports victories, and a series of technical innovations during the 1950s. Packard can boast three important achievements in automotive history: it was the first in America to introduce wheel steering instead of tiller steering, the first to install air conditioning as well as electric windows, and the first to install central locking on popular models.

The model on display is very characteristic for its ‘avalve’ engine, i.e., with a sleeve valve timing instead of traditional valves, built under licence from the American company Knight. Another special feature of the car with its ‘coupé de ville’ bodywork is the internal heating system using hot water inserted into the engine cooling circuit. In 1965, the brand was taken over by Citroën and finally ceased production in 1967, a century after it was founded.

Among those who contributed to shap- ing the history of locomotion was Enrico Pecori from Lombardy (1854-1941), who was fascinated by the new means of transport that were just beginning to appear in Italy. He was one of the first ‘velocipedists’ to ride on the roads of Milan and Lombardy, a founding member of the Unione Velocipedisti Italiani (Italian Velocipedists Union) and of the Touring Club, and it was probably this passion that led him to study the possibility of creating a small self-propelled vehicle. After two years of testing, Pecori suc- ceeded in completing his steam tricycle: it was equipped with a 2-cylinder hori- zontal engine with steam distribution by means of a flat box.

In 1891, Peugeot produced the ‘Type 3’, of which 64 were built; among them, the model on display, with chassis no. 25 and engine no. 124 from the German Daimler factory, representing a milestone in the history of motoring in Italy: it was the first car to circulate in the country. It was ordered on 30 August 1892 by Gaetano Rossi, sold to Guido Lazzari and brought by Carlo Biscaretti di Ruffia. The Peugeot participated in the London to Brighton Veteran Car Run in 2017, 2018 and 2019

It is powered by an electric motor providing about 3,4 kW, fed by a battery pack of 40 Nichel-Cadmio units, providing 1,9 kWh. The 18 high efficiency monocrystalline solar panels mounted on the wings provide energy to the batteries; their rated power is 0,6 kW, according to the available sun’s energy. The electronic control unit manages both the recharging of the batteries and the powering of the motor.

Prinetti & Stucchi is an old Italian company founded in Milan in 1874 for the manufacture of sewing machines and bicycles. From 1898 onwards, Prinetti & Stucchi also produced tricycles, four-wheelers, and small cars. The first model was designed by a very young (barely seventeen) Ettore Bugatti, a talented technician destined for great fame, who mounted a De Dion engine (or rather, two coupled, with a power of 3 HP) on a pedal tricycle manufactured by the company. He was also responsible for the next design, a four-wheeler with two De Dion engines fitted to the rear wheels

The AG model was built at the behest of Louis Renault from 1905 and used as a public service car (
fiacre
) for the city of Paris. The car had a free/busy flag and above all was equipped with a taximeter, from which the name ‘taxi’ derived. The taxi became a popular means of transport in the
ville lumière
, the most motorised city in the world at the time, and by 1914 there were around 10,000 taxis on the roads, of which 8,500 were the AG model.

The US car manufacturer REO, founded in 1904 by Ransom Eli Olds, began pro- duction with two separate models, one with a single-cylinder engine and one with a 2-cylinder engine. The single-cylinder model had an output of 8 HP and could reach a top speed of 45 km/h. The engine was placed horizontally in the middle of the car, under the two seats. The vehicle had an elegant front bonnet, which was, of course, fake, and purely for aesthetic purposes. The twin-cylinder model was not dissimilar, although bigger and faster: it was able to exceed 60 km/h and carry five people in the ‘touring’ version. In both cases they were simple and inexpensive but very efficient cars

The history of the famous English factory began in 1904 when the first car built by founder Henry Royce was released. He was joined by the eccentric aristocrat Charles Stewart Rolls, an enthusiastic young driver and dealer in London for the luxurious French Panhard cars. The model that enshrined the excellence of the brand and its supremacy over any other luxury icon was the 40-50 HP, better known as the Silver Ghost, considered the initiator of the Rolls- Royce legend, in production from 1907 to 1926.

The first Sizaire-Naudin was presented at the Paris Salon in 1905. It was a simple and robust sports car with a single-cylinder front engine of around 900 cc. The frame was made of wood strengthened by metal reinforcements. Externally, the two-seater was characterised by a large transverse leaf spring on the front suspension, coupled to shock absorbers following a system previously adopted by Décauville. The Sizaire-Naudin, thanks to its low weight and reasonably lively engine, boasted brilliant performance and was successfully used in small car races

The commercial success at the dawn of 1900 prompted the French company Krieger, which specialised in electric and ‘hybrid’ vehicles, to open a branch in Turin, which in 1907 took the name STAE (Società Torinese Automo- bili Elettriche). A light four-seater car and a two-seater car with internal drive were presented at the Turin Exhibi- tion that year. The peculiarity of these models was their low weight (800 kg) and good range (80 km). The car in the Museum is fitted with a centrally positioned electric motor with a cardan shaft transmission and battery power supply, housed in the false bonnet.

The record-breaking car with ‘twin torpedo’ bodywork designed by engineer Piero Taruffi consists of two separate steel tube chassis and ‘teardrop’ cladding. The tubular structure forms two highly profiled elements, one housing the driver and the second for the engine, a Gilera motorbike engine. The transmission of the engine to the two rear drive wheels is by chain. The steering control is by means of levers that replace the steering wheel. The gearbox and clutch are operated by a hand lever located between the driver’s legs. Brake control is hydraulic on all four wheels

With the aim of making a utility car that was small and economical both in price and handling, Temperino’s manufacturing activities continued throughout the 1910s and the first half of the 1920s. The air-cooled 2-cylinder engine was the hallmark of these utility cars. The 8/10 HP model was the first model built by Temperino and was successful in Italy and abroad for its economy and handling.

The vehicle was created by converting a suitably reinforced ‘landau’ type horse-drawn carriage. At the rear, Bordino placed a steam boiler using coke as fuel; under the passenger compartment, between the wooden side sections
of the carriage frame, the engine was positioned, consisting of two horizontal cylinders with a box distribution. It circulated on the streets of Turin between 1854 and 1860, consuming 30 kg of coke per hour and reaching a speed of 8 km per hour

The automotive engineering adopted for the small Trabant was essential. The engine, a two-stroke, was initially designed for motorbike use. The first P50 model, produced from 1957 to 1962 with 131,440 units, was a 2-stroke 500 cc; with the Trabant P601, the most popular model, the displacement increased to 594 cc, with a power output of 26 HP. The engine was only ‘updated’ after the fall of the Wall: for the first time the 601 was fitted with a four-stroke 1043 cc engine derived from the Volkswagen Polo. The chassis consisted of a steel sheet platform supporting an ultra-lightweight 650 kg body made of a special plastic material called Duroplast, composed of resin reinforced with recycled and pressed wool or cotton.

The first car produced was a carriage with a water-cooled vertical twin- cylinder front engine, sold in England as ‘La Silencieuse’, 1.5-litre capacity, automatic intake valves and controlled side exhaust valves. It was characterized by the gear stick control consisting of a long central lever. In 1903 came the company’s first 4-cylinder car, with a 3300 cc anti-clockwise 2-block engine with 2-side valve timing system and an output of 14 HP at 1100 rpm

A car with innovative mechanics. In fact, it featured a chassis with independently suspended wheels and torsion bar springing as well as friction disk shock absorbers, a power-assisted effect (achieved by means of eccentrics in the tie rod braking system), a soft rubber engine suspension, and a 985 cc air-cooled, opposed 4-stroke 4-cylinder engine, mounted in a rear overhang position with the gearbox facing forward. The highly aerodynamic bodywork was also revolutionary.
